Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Maybe tonight?

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Whaddyamean 'maybe'?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's what he said.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: He doesn't know? How come he doesn't know?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't know how he doesn't know.He doesn't know.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Sonofabitch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wonder who his supplier is.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I wasn't asking.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: He never leaves the beach, Fat Sam. Never leaves. Sits in that chair, he's outta junk. Then he suddenly gets up, he's got junk. So where does it come from? Through the sand?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think that's highly unlikely, Creasy.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: I ought to get some sleep.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Creasy, how old are you?

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Nineteen.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You're not taking real good care of yourself.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Excuse me.I have something I'd like to discuss with you.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: We can't talk about it here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Because we can't.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Are you on a scavenger hunt of some kind?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I want you to come to my house. Then we'll talk.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think you've got the wrong gal, fella.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I'll give you a thousand dollars cash just to come to my house and listen to the proposition. If you reject the proposition, you keep the thousand, and your mouth shut.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Will this proposition entail my dressing up as Tina Turner?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: One thousand, just to listen.I don't see how you could turn that down Mr...

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Nugent. Ted Nugent.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Alan Stanwyk.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Charmed.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I always liked this part of town.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What a coincidence.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I came this close...  ...to buying this place

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Then I found out Hopalong Cassidy had shot himself in the game room. That just blew it for me.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hopalong Cassidy. Killed himself here. Bow and arrow. Strange.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: What are you, doped up or something?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't work for you yet, assface. Don't talk to me like that.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Come inside.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Buenas dias.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: Buenas dias.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I commend you on your Spanish.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Ahh, the library. Masculine but sensitive.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Really, I love what you've done with the place. Must have cost you...hundreds.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Here's my proposition, Mr. Fletcher.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm all ears.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I want you to murder me.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Here. On Thursday. I'd like you to shoot me dead.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: The reason I ask you to do me this service is that I am facing a long, painful, and most certain death. You see, I have bone cancer. I don't know if you know anything about bone cancer.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: It doesn't get any worse than that. Just eats you up, bit by bit.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You don't look sick, Mr. Stanwyk.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I don't feel sick. Not yet. They tell me it'll start getting bad in about a month. After that... well, I'd rather not be around for it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why don't you try suicide?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: My company has taken out a very large insurance policy on me. And I have a wife. Suicide would nullify my insurance. Murder does not.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So why pick me?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: You're a drifter, a -- pardon the expression -- beach bum. No one would notice if you disappeared. I've watched you for a couple weeks.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Maybe I'm just on vacation.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Not with the scum you hang out with. I've watched. I've thought. Its a perfect scheme. I even have a perfect escape plan for you.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Did it ever occur to you that I might not want to kill you?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I've got fifty thousand dollars says you will.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Fifty thousand and a guarantee you won't get caught.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm still here.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: These will be open.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wouldn't they normally be locked?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Sometimes yes, sometimes no. The staff usually forgets.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I have the same problem with my help.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I will be here in the room, waiting for you. The safe will be open and there will be fifty thousand dollars in it. You will be wearing rubber gloves. Do you own rubber gloves?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I rent them. Monthly lease, with an option to buy.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: In this drawer....

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Very good. My .357. Use it and no one can trace it to you. The room will be in some disarray.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So it looks like a burglary attempt. You catch me. I get the gun, and shoot you.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Precisely. Are you a good shot?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's the difference? The noise'll kill you first.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Get me on the first shot, if you can.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't think you'll have to worry about that.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Do you have a passport?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sure, all drifters do.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Fine. After you kill me, take the Jaguar. The keys will be in the glove compartment.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Take it where?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: LAX. Go to the Pan Am desk. There will be a ticket waiting for you.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Where am I going?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: They serve dinner on the flight?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: It'll be a first class-ticket. I'm sure you'll enjoy the ride. I would recommend staying down there at least a year, Mr. Fletcher.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You've certainly thought this out, haven't you?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: I am not someone who leaves a great deal to chance, Mr. Fletcher.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You sure those doors will be open?

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Yes. All you provide are the gloves, the passport, and the aim. I'll take care of everything else.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: The gun, the money, the tickets, and the dying.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You sure got the hard part.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: What do you say, Mr. Fletcher? You'll be doing me and my family a great service.

Speaker: stanwyk
Dialogue: Will you kill me?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Whoa, check out the beach boy!

Speaker: second reporter
Dialogue: Looking very good, Fletch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank you so much  Hey, Larry!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Yo!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can I steal you for a minute?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Only if you promise not to return me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Deal.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: 'Magic' today, huh?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Kareem's in the wash. I need a favor.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Shoot.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Don't say shoot, okay.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch. Fletch!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Did you hear something?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Not me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Me neither. See what we've got on a guy named Alan Stanwyk, okay? I need it right away.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch, I take it by your presence here that the story is done. Tell me I'm right.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: W-Y-K no 'c.' I'll be down in a minute.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: No problem, boss.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Frank, you look a little peaked. Wanna vomit?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: No, I want an answer, Is the story done?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Uh, almost.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: 'Uh, almost' is not an answer. 'Yes Frank, it's all done': that's an answer.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: And a damn fine one, I might add.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Two....

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Irwin....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, I hate it when he calls me that.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Irwin, professional journalism time, now. Go back to the goddamn beach and finish the goddamn story!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I will, Frank, I will. Something came up, okay?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: No it's not okay. You have to have this in by tomorrow. Did you see the ad we ran Sunday?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I never read the paper.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: ...never reads the paper...

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's the spread on the game tonight?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I don't know.  Look!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Looks great.

Speaker: next week
Dialogue: A "JANE DOE" SPECIAL REPORT: DRUGS ON OUR BEACHES - SHAME OF THE CITY

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'Shame of Our City' is so good.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Now, Irwin, try to follow me. You can't run the ad and then not run the story.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why not? Oh $hit...really?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Just kidding, Frank. You'll have the story and you'll be damn proud of it.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You broke it? You know the source?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Practically.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What's 'practically'? Is it Fat Sam? You said you had pictures of him....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I have pictures of him. Dealing....

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: So let's go! We run the pictures.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He's not the story! There's a source behind him.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Well, there we're in a gray area.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: How gray?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'd say charcoal.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I'm going to bite out your eyeballs, you know that?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Frank, you animal, I love it. I'll have the story by Thursday night, I swear to God.  I hope.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'Mr. Stanwyk, of Provo, Utah, is a former commercial pilot.'

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Married Boyd Aviation. He's no dummy, that's serious coin.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Not our kind of people, you understand.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Spot right here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: You doing a story on this guy?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I wonder if that's his doctor.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Only one way to find out.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: We play tennis at the club.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Well, I haven't played in a while because of these kidney pains.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's Babar.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: One. B-a-b-a-r.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: But not right next to each other. I thought that's what you meant.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't know. I don't have any.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No books. No elephants either. No really good elephant books.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, I don't belong formally. I've gone with my aunt.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Mrs. Smith.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Margaret.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Is she ever. I've got some stories....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It was. Really a shame. To go so suddenly.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sure, but the end was so sudden.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yes, but the very end, when he actually died, that was extremely sudden.  You know, Alan and I were recently speaking of dying. Told me Boyd Aviation took out a lot of insurance on him. You must have to be in some kind of perfect health to get that kind of policy.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh really, there's no need to -- we don't want to do that....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Honest, I feel fine. You better be married.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Did I say 'kidneys'? I meant my ear. Maybe I should see an ear dahhh --  Ever serve time?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Anyway, I'm surprised Alan got the policy so easily. I know there's a history of cancer in the family.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Whoa, look out there. You really need the whole fist?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gee, Alan's been looking kind of sick lately. Is he all right?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm sure it's not for a lack of looking. Maybe I should get a real complete physical. You give Alan an annual, don't you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I hope they still fit. Do I get to keep the glove?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thanks, Doc. Maybe I'll come back with a date. Or an elephant.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Identification please.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's me doctor Rosenpenis. I just have to take another peek at Alan Stanwyk's file. What have they done with this place?

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Nothing. They're still there.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Right. Fine.

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: Hey you!

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: Give me a hand for a second would you doctor?

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: Come on, come on.

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: Have you ever see a spleen this large?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Not recently.

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: Grab this, will you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Uh, I'm not really prepared. My hands aren't sterilized.

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: You're not going to make this guy any sicker.

Speaker: pathologist
Dialogue: You never really get used to the smell, do you?

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Are you all right, Doctor?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Where am I?

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: You're in the Records Room.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm fine.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Can I get you something?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Have you got a make-shift plywood pillory? Heh Heh, just kidding.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Doctor Holmes went to get you some smelling salts. He was quite surprised that you fainted.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Well, I didn't want to say anything, but I thought the dead man was my brother.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Oh my God!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's all right. It wasn't him but that spleen was a splitting image.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, God, I think I'm about to hyperventilate. Have you got a paper bag, or something.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Yes, right away.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Here you are, Doctor.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Is there anything particular you're looking for?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: My associates did a biopsy on this man recently.  He's supposed to have a melanoma, or a carcinoma, some kind of noma. Hmmm. I can't seem to find any record of it.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: Wait. Here it is. Yep. Surgical removal of two moles. Tissue was benign.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's it?

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: That's it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: This was last month. So Alan Stanwyk does not have cancer.

Speaker: records nurse
Dialogue: I guess not.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He'll be so relieved.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Christ.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: Refusal to pay alimony is a jailable offense, Fletch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What about breaking and entering?  Are you wearing anything under that?

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: I did not break nor enter. I simply chose an advisable location to await my client's delinquent husband.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I hate to conduct business on the lanai. Why don't we step inside.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: One on one?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: And the foul.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: You owe Wendy nine hundred and eighteen dollars.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: She doesn't need the money, for crissakes. She's living with Monty. I know it.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: I don't know what you're referring to. Wendy maintains her own residence.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It stinks. I thought woman were independent now.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: Until she remarries, Fletch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hey, shut up, okay? I just hate this.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: I empathize with your plight, Fletch. However, you threw her out.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: She was sleeping with everybody. The cable TV guy. You can't get lower than that....

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: You should have proved that in a court of law.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: My lawyer was a bum.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: I agree.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think he was sleeping with Wendy, too.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: You may be right.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Are you serious?

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: That's history, Fletch. You owe us nine hundred and eighteen dollars.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wait a minute! Our problems might be solved.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think I just won a million dollars!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Damn...lost again. Sorry.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: This is no joke. If some kind of payment isn't made, we're going to have to contact the paper and garnish your wages.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: Cash. I'm impressed.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Found it in a cab. That's a grand. Apply the difference to next month.

Speaker: gillett
Dialogue: Till then.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank God.

Speaker: hearn
Dialogue: How about Fletch?

Speaker: jabbar
Dialogue: Well, Fletch has been great. He's super-strong, really clogs the middle for us, boxes out, gets the bounds....

Speaker: hearn
Dialogue: Now here's a key play in Tuesday night's game....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gail Stanwyk!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I haven't seen you since the wedding, Jeez, you look great.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Huh? No, not my wedding. Yours.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: We used to fly together. I'm...John.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: John Ultrarelamensky.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's Scotch-Rumanian.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So were my parents.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Excuse me sir. Are you a guest of the club?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yes, I'm with the Underhills.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: They just left, sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: They'll be back. He had to go in for a urinalysis.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Would you care for a drink while you're waiting? I can put it on the Underhill bill.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Great. I'll have a Bloody Mary and a steak sandwich.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Very good sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You should play with much larger tennis balls. So how's Alan?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Preoccupied with what?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Good. Lobs are a very important part of the game.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why do you keep doing this?

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: I love the outfits.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Try stepping into the ball with your left foot.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: There, much better.

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: Stay!  I must be having an off day. I'm really a fabulous player.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I have this effect on lots of women.

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: I bet you do.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Say, the reason I asked about Alan is that I bumped into him this morning and you know what I can't figure out?

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: Alan's in Utah.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I can't figure out why I went to Utah for the morning.

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: Okay. I'm delighted to have someone to talk to, and you're very cute, so I'm very flattered, but I'm also very married so you may as well forget -- You are trying to hit on me, aren't you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm such a heel. How'd you guess?

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: If I had a nickel for every one of Alan's flyboy buddies who tried to pick me up, I'd be a rich woman.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You are a rich woman.

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: See what I mean?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's he doing in Utah?

Speaker: mrs stanwyk
Dialogue: None of your business, now go away. You're throwing my game off.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: ...then who walks in but George Bush. He took one look around the room...

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: ...and said 'Sorry Mr. President, I thought it was Saturday.'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I thought I was going to die.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Sugar, Mr. Poon?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: First of all, let me just reiterate that this is not a formal investigation. I'm not going through formal channels here, because if Alan Stanwyk is not involved in any improprieties, then nobody has to know I was even ---

Speaker: boyd
Dialogue: Alan Stanwyk is not involved in improprieties. Where the hell does the S.E.C. come off ---

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Look. You know that and I know that, but somebody's bucking for a promotion. I think it's that bozo, Hanrahan, I can't be sure. Anyway, unless I go back there with something, you and your son-in-law are next week's scapegoats.

Speaker: boyd
Dialogue: Unbelievable.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I feel like dirt. They even want to know what he's doing in Utah?

Speaker: boyd
Dialogue: Utah?  Jesus Christ! First of all, Alan Stanwyk does not own one share of stock.The three million dollars for the ranch in Provo comes from my daughter who converted some of her personal holdings, not company holdings. Now if anybody in DC wants to make something of that, bring 'em on. Until then, get the hell out of my face.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: God I admire you.

Speaker: boyd
Dialogue: By the way: what kind of name is Poon?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Comanche Indian.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, Margie, sorry, Frieda lost the number of Alan's realtor in Provo. Can you give it to me real quick?

Speaker: margie
Dialogue: Jim Swarthout?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: margie
Dialogue: And, I'm sorry, who are you again?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Frieda's boss.

Speaker: margie
Dialogue: Who's Frieda?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: My secretary.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: See if you've got anything in Stanwyk's background from when he lived in Utah. Also check on a realtor in Provo named Swarthout. And tell Frank I'm crazy about him and I'd like to discuss his maybe moving in with me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Later.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Fletch! Take off!

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: They're after Gummy again. It's weird.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Fletch, slow down.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hey, what are you doing?

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Fletch, this is dumb.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You don't have to run with me, Crease.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why are you beating up on that kid?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He's defenseless, and you kick the crap out of him. What do you want from ---

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Fletch!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What goddamn right do you have to take him?

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Fletch!!!

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: Hey you're really nuts.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: They didn't do anything.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: What? What are you talking about?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I busted their window, they didn't do anything.

Speaker: creasy
Dialogue: You're lucky.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Not luck. They don't want me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gummy and two cops....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Cool your tool, Frank, I need a little more time. I think I'm really on to something here.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Your onto something. That's good. What?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I really don't want to spoil your surprise, Frank. Why don't you read it tomorrow?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Speak, don't point!

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I need Fletch for a second.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: She needs me, Frank.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Nothing on Gail Stanwyk, nothing on Jim Swarthout. But I did ---

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's okay, Lar. I gotta put this on the back burner for a while.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Just give me a hint, all right?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: All right. Maybe there are some crooked cops involved in all this.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: Did you say cops?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: That's one thing I did find. It's from Last month, so it was in the unsorted pile.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think I gotta go to Utah, Frank.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Utah?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah. It's wedged in between Wyoming and Nevada. I'm sure you've seen pictures.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What about finding the source?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I have some ideas.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Who? Donnie and Marie?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Very possibly. Come on, say yes. I'll buy you a shirt.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Go to transportation, get a ticket.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: My hero.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Nothing to it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hi, Jim Swarthout, please. Oh, hello, my name is Igor Stravinski and I'm looking for some ranch property.

Speaker: swarthout
Dialogue: Good, Mr. Starinski, what'd you have in mind?  Uh huh. Oh are you a friend of Alan's?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No, I just heard some people at the club talking about the property you sold him, and the way it was described, three million sounded like a pretty good price.  What?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Are you sure?  Of course. I guess I was misinformed. Listen, I'd love to come out and see you anyway. When are you available?

Speaker: swarthout
Dialogue: Well, I'm about to close up shop and go out for the evening. How about first thing in the AM?  Great. See you tomorrow.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Tomorrow.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's your name fella? Fluff? Pom-pom?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sh*t.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sit-tuh!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Roll over. Play dead. Good boy.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You any relation to Doctor Dolan?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I hate this.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Make sure nobody comes in, okay?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Suck on this Cujo!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gimme a smile! There you go...oh, that's a nice one...  Everything's fine, now...go take a little nap....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Look! Defenseless babies!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That dog is such an A**hole.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'Bil-lie, Bil-lie...'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: If I took that out, you guys couldn't fit in here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You just planted that.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Read me my rights.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hold it! I'll waive my rights.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Who we booking here, gentlemen?

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Oh Yeah?  You'll like the Chief. Nice man.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I hear he's mellowed a lot since he came out of the closet.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: I find he gets real mellow after he hits somebody a lot.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Easy fellas.  Be with you in just a second.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You decorate this yourself or did Mrs. Chief of Police help you?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: So what's your name?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Fletch.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Full name.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Fletch F. Fletch

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: I see. And what do you do for a living, Mr. Fletch?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm President of the International Fletch Corporation.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Why are you doing this Mr. Fletch?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Frankly sir, you look a little like my father. Probaly explains the curious feeling of love I have for you.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: For a gentleman who was just found holding a bag full of heroin....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It was planted on me, sir.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: We're looking at five years, maybe ten. Is that what you want...Jane Doe?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Your editor called me yesterday to respond to allegations you're about to print about police involvement in narcotics dealing.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: I'm about to break that beach wide open, and I don't need some pennyante Woodward and Bernstein getting in the way of my men.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'Your men' might just be involved in all this.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: You idiot. Off the record, deep background: I've got that beach crawling with undercover cops.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: If you keep nosing around, you make the bad guys just a little bit more cautious. That makes my job harder. And if you print your story this week, you might get some of my men killed. I can't let that happen, Mr. Fletch.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: You go back to that goddamn beach, I swear to God I'll make you regret it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hey, you and Tommy Lasorda. That's great.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't like Tommy Lasorda.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You can't keep me here.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Maybe I'm not going to keep you here.  Maybe I'm gonna blow your brains out.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm no lawyer, but I do believe that's a violation of my rights.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: After I shoot you, I stick the knife in my arm, then place it in your dead hand. Self-defense. We don't do this very much anymore...but we have. Got rid of a lot of minorities that way.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: My God, you're serious.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Ask anybody.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can I ask anybody now?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can I call my Mom? I'd like to tell here how much I've always loved her.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: What'll it be Fletch?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I hate the beach. Wouldn't go there if you paid me. Besides, I'm way overdue on my story about off-track betting in the Himalayas. You don't think it's the mafia, do you?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Its been very nice meeting you. I enjoy your column.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Speaking of which, you're not going to print anything before my investigation is through, are you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Not a prayer.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: That a boy.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Thanks for coming down to see us.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Not at all, Chief. But next time...no tongue, okay?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: How could you call him?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: It's called journalism, Fletch. It's called getting both sides of the story. Something you apparently don't know anything about.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's also called getting me this close to being murdered.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Get out of here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He threw me in a cell, took a gun and a knife and threatened to kill me right there if I didn't promise to give up the story.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You know, I've had it up to here with your bullsh*t. I need a story from you by tomorrow.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You'll have it.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: But not unsubstantiated charges about dope-dealing cops, and not horse sh*t paranoid fantasies about homicidal police chiefs.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thanks for the vote of confidence, Frank.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I want something I can print!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Print this Frank.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hi, where's Mrs. Stanwyk?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: In her cabana, sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, that's right. She told me to meet her there. That's cabana six?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Cabana one.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: One.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Would you be caring for something to eat or drink, sir?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I would, actually.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Charged to the Underhills, sir?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Right. Tell you what -- have you caviar?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Yes, sir. Beluga. But it is eighty dollars the portion.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'd better only get two. How about the lobster thermidor?

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: I recommend it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Fine. And a couple of bottles of Dom Perignon. To cabana one.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Very good, sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: This is just the nicest place.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's John. John...  Znhcneelsky.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hi.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I was hoping you'd say that.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can I borrow your towel for a minute?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I ordered lunch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Well, I knew this is where my mouth would be.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No, I think you should stay the same wonderful person you are today.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Here, take mine.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Lunch....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: You want I set up?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No thanks, I'll do it. Give yourself twenty dollars. Underhill.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Muchas gracias.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sierra del fuego.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I saved his life during the war.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No. He was. I got him out.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Your guest, sir.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: I believe he's with Mrs. Stanwyk.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Yes sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'I've been so many places in my life and times. I've sung a lot of songs, I've made some bad rhymes....'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'I've acted out my life on stages, with ten thousand people watching....'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'But we're alone now, and I'm singing this song for you.'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can I ask you a question?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Are you still in love with Alan?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Why'd you let me in?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thanks, I feel much better. Listen, if you're so bored, why didn't you go to Utah with Alan?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Good point.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What about his parents?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: How come?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thanks for the great time.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Long story.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Take one end.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'll be leaving now, Mrs. Stanwyk.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gail. I hope this won't embarrass you in any way. I think Underhill's a yutz, you won't have any trouble with him.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah. My name's not John Ultramalensky and I wasn't at your wedding.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Irwin Fletcher. I write a newspaper column under the name Jane Doe.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So, your husband hired me to kill him. That's the truth.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's what I want to know.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He told me he was dying of cancer. Not True. That ranch you thought you were paying for in Utah? Not true.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He's a bad guy, Mrs. Stanwyk. Gail. I think he's involved in something very big and very bad.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Have you ever heard the name Jim Swarthout?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wrong. He sold you $3,000 worth of scrub brush.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You saw a forgery.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's the real deed.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Here's this dog that tried to eat me. Here's my motel. Here's the car I rented....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't know. All I know is that he told me a lot of things and so far not one of them has been true.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm really sorry I have to tell you all this.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No. You can't. Look, I know you don't know me from Adam, but you've got to trust me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Just give me twenty-four hours. Please. Someone almost killed me today. People are not being nice lately, and I don't want you getting hurt. I think you're terrific. Are you a Laker fan?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'll take you to a game.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm talking about how much I'd like to take you to a Laker game.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Act natural.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: If you need me, call the paper. Hand me that extra bottle okay?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Jesus.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Should've known. Goddamn it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Great. First I'll get a speeding ticket, then they'll shoot me. Terrific.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: All right, fella, smog check. Move over.

Speaker: teenager
Dialogue: Holy sh*t!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sorry, youngster, but we have to see what kind of fluorocarbons this thing puts out at ninety-five.

Speaker: teenager
Dialogue: Holy sh*t!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Don't worry about the speed limit. That's what the police escort's for.

Speaker: teenager
Dialogue: Okay, okay, just stop, will you. I admit it. I stole it. I was just taking it for a little joy ride, that's all....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Holy sh*t.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Okay, kid. Just stand here with your hands on the car and wait for the cops. I gotta pee. Here, take my hat.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ...and he can truly be called the Father of Internal Bushings.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hello. I'm with the hotel catering. Are you enjoying your meal? Carrots overcooked?

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: And now a man who needs no further introduction....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank you, Tony, thank you. As a lifelong friend of....  ...Fred Dorfman, I'm thrilled to be here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Many of you are probably not aware of Freddie's lifelong commitment to honoring a profession that frequently goes unsung -- the police. Many times Fred used to forsake a night with his wife and children to go out an sell tickets for the Policemen's Benevolent Association.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Our men in blue are with us today, and I think we should all extend a shake of the hand, a slap on the back and a 'howdy' to them.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: When was the last time you hugged a cop? Do it for my good friend Tommy Lasorda. Doesn't it feel good? Don't you wish you'd done it long ago?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Let them know how we feel, with a song. For every cop on every beat in every city of this great nation.  'For he's a jolly good fellow....'

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yes sir, you are confirmed on Flight 306 to Rio tomorrow evening at 11 PM. First Class.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You're kidding.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Would you like me to change anything?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So he's going. Uh...are there any other tickets charged to the same account?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: We'd have no way of knowing that, sir.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Hmm. It's just that there are some other people from my office going on this trip and...is there anyone in the seat next to me?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yes, there is. Cavanaugh.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Never heard of him. Thanks anyway.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: You mean her.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Sally Ann Cavanaugh. Oh wait, she couldn't work in your office, she's not from around here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Oh, thanks.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: She's from Utah.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'Bom-ba-bom-bom...bommmm.'

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Who the hell are you?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Get up.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: The door was unlocked.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Lock's busted.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No wonder.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I work for the landlord. He told me to watch out for the place.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I commend him on his choice.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I commend him on his choice

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I was supposed to meet Mrs. Cavanaugh.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Don Corleone. I'm a cousin of Mrs. Cavanaugh's.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Where is she?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Moved out.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: She moved out?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I spoke to her last week. She didn't say anything.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: She moved out.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: So you're saying she moved out.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: This morning.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: This morning? Christ. We had so much to talk about. Moe Green is out of the Tropicana, and my sons, Michael and Fredo, are taking over.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: What did you want under the bed?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Mattress police. There are no tags on the mattress. I'm going to have to take you downtown. Please give me your weapon.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'm calling the cops. This is for the cops.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm her cousin.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Tell the cops.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Go ahead. Call them. Better tie your shoelaces first.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm getting real tired of all this hostility.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Evening.  They oughta recall these things. One bump,the whole window goes.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Are you Mr. Marvin Stanwyk?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm Harry S. Truman from Casewell Insurance Underwriters.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Harry S. Truman?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: My parents were great fans of the former President.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Isn't that nice. Good man. Showed the Japs a thing or two.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sure did. Dropped the big one on them.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Dropped two big ones. Real fighter. You're in the insurance line, Harry?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Well, I'm fully covered.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't doubt it, Mr. Stanwyk. Actually, my company is the sub-insurer of the subsidiary carriers of a policy held by Alan Stanwyk, who I believe is your son.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Yes. Where you from, Harry?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: California. San Berdoo. Utah's part of my route. Can I ask you a few questions?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: First, a couple of routine things: are you and you wife currently alive?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Regulations, Mr. Stanwyk. And you and your wife, named....

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Velma.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Velma. You and Velma are the parents of Alan Stanwyk, Beverly Hills, California, executive vice president of Boyd Aviation?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Check.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Okay.  Now, the last time you saw your son was when?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Oh, about ten days ago.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Ten days ago?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: That's right. Alan comes by every three weeks or so.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Isn't that nice. Since when?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Since he moved to L.A.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Forgive me now for seeming personal, but we understand that there is a lady friend he sees here in Provo.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: What the hell does this have to do with insurance?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Trust me, sir. It's a comprehensive policy.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Well, you can forget about that lady friend business, Alan's the most loyal husband a girl could have. He dotes on that bride of his.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Cute young thing, too.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm sorry?

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: His bride. Cute as a button.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You've met her?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Well, of course we have. He brings her with him.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Has Alan ever mentioned the name Sally Ann Cavanaugh?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Has he?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Boy, what the hell's the matter with you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Then he has.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Course he has. That's his wife.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Of course, his wife's name is Sally Ann Cavanaugh?

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Cute thing.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Do you happen to have a picture of Alan and his wife?

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Oh, we've got lots of pictures. Let me show you some.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: And they're still married...Alan and Sally Ann.

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Of course they are.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: She's cute as a button.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: How long have they been married?

Speaker: marvin
Dialogue: Lets see, it was before he moved to L.A...four years April.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Mrs. Stanwyk, may I borrow this picture. I promise to send it back to you. It's routine, really. The actuarial people need to ---

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Oh, that's all right, I've got lots more. Want to see the reception?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No, thank you.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: How about Marvin's sixty-fifth birthday party?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Frank told you that?

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I overheard it. He thinks you're completely out of control, he said he was gonna can you as soon as he got the story. If I were you, I'd just chuck it, Fletch. Screw him. Let him eat three full pages on Sunday.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You kidding? I got an unbelievable story here, Lar. Un-believable. Jesus. It's the cops, I know it. The Chief! And they're all over Frank.

Speaker: larry
Dialogue: I just thought...sure.  Sally Ann Cavanaugh.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Check every hotel in L.A. Start with the ones near the airport. Yeah. He's about to leave the country with her. Thanks, Lar.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'welluh bless my soul whatsuh wrong with me? I'ma itchin' like a man Inuh fuzzy tree....'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Yeah...No kidding. The Marriott at LAX. Sonofabitch...Checked in this morning. Great. Thanks a million. And call Gail Stanwyk at the Racquet Club. Tell her I have to meet her tonight. Eight o'clock at the club. Urgent and confidential. Thanks.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Question:

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Question....

Speaker: tape recorder
Dialogue: Day three on the beach. Fat Sam still hasn't moved, and ---

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's wrong with my life?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Question: Why does a man marry a millionaire's daughter in Beverly Hills if he is already married to a girl who lives in a crappy one bedroom apartment in Utah? Answer: Three million dollars. Big Question: What's with Stanwyk and Cummings? I don't know. Bigger Question: Why does Stanwyk want me to kill him?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Miss, I believe this has already been eaten.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What's wrong, Gail?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I think you better sit down.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gail, please.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I got this from Alan's parents. By the way, they see him all the time.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I checked. There was no divorce.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm telling you he's not your husband at all.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: And they're leaving the country tomorrow night.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I don't have all the pieces yet, but I'm close. I'll know tomorrow.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You cant do that.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: They're trying to kill me!

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You're going to have to trust me, Gail. You have to. Now listen to me: he's expecting you to go to your meeting tomorrow night. Do it. Stay out of the house.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Come here.

Speaker: surfer cop
Dialogue: A Sufi junkie.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gum?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm the Sufi.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: Fletch?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Don't call me Fletch. Don't look at me. Lie back down. We'll talk.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Cops are here. I can smell them. They're after me. Lie down, Gum.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: Why are they after you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Because I'm a newspaper reporter and I'm nailing Chief Cummings as the source for drugs on the beach. You're in big trouble, Gummy.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sit back down.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Fat Sam is turning state's evidence.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He wrote me a nice deposition. He says he just received the drugs. You did the selling.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: I didn't sell nothing! I didn't sell nothing! I just carried the drugs from the Chief to Sam.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Sure you did.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: Fletch, I never sold nothing.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Twenty years.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Can't do a thing with this robe. One more question, Gum...don't look at me.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Where does the Chief get the drugs?

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: I dunno. Somewhere in South America, I forget.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Rio de Janeiro, maybe?

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: Maybe, Fletch. Is that Brazil?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That's Brazil.

Speaker: gummy
Dialogue: Yeah. Maybe.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wait here for me, Gummy.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: It's the only way you'll be safe. Believe me.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Jesus.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You don't know me.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: My pleasure.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm serious, Sam.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: What, the heat here?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Affirmative.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: The two surfer boys?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Affirmative.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Thought so. What for?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: For me. I'm a reporter, Sam. I'm breaking the drug story and I got the chief red-handed. Gummy game me a deposition.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: You gonna nail the chief?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm gonna nail the chief. And you can help or ---

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Oh, I'll help, Fletch. I'm a slave to that sonofabitch. He busted me, third offense, gave me a choice: Work for him or do fifteen long. All I get out of this is free snort.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You don't have a piece of the action?

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Noooo. Free snort. That's it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Wait five minutes, and go to my office. You'll get federal protection after that.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Gonna need it. That boy is dangerous. Fletch?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: You find the source?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gum thought Brazil.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: Rio. Know how he gets it in the country? Some big shot airline executive flies it in on company jets. Very impressive operation, Fletch. Very impressive.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm quitting, Frank. As of midnight tonight.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What?  Who the hell are they?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: This is Fat Sam, and this is Gummy.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Their statements, naming Chief Cummings as the numero uno drug pusher from here to Oxnard. I want them to have federal protection under the paper's sponsorship.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Jesus H. Christ.  Fletch, this is the greatest.

Speaker: fat sam
Dialogue: He's some reporter, this guy.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm out, Frank. You lost faith in me.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch, I got nervous. Please....

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm going to write the story. Just hold the last couple of paragraphs till ten o'clock tonight.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Make yourselves comfortable, guys, but don't leave the office.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch!

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch, you want an apology?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You were going to can me, right?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Not really.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Not really?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I was upset.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm sick of this place. I'm going to try out for the Lakers. They need a power forward.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Fletch.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I like your outfit. You got the fifty grand and the plane ticket?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Because I trust you, Alan. By the way, the name's Fletcher. I.M. Fletcher. I write a newspaper column under the name Jane Doe.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Read this, please.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Cut the crap and read it.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Unless my people hear differently, this letter goes out at midnight.

Speaker: john boyd
Dialogue: CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD BOYD AVIATION

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Pretty hefty. Keep reading.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You shouldn't be here.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: He doesn't read my stuff well.  That was stupid, Alan.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Ahem.  'Sally Ann can confirm all this when the police pick her up at the Airport Marriott.'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: 'By the way, Alan is a very big drug smuggler, but you can read all about that in tomorrow's paper. Sincerely yours, I.M. Fletcher. P.S. Have a nice day.'

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: The thing that really tipped it off for me was something your wife said to me while we were in bed together.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: How similar in build you and I are. then I figured it. You bump me off, throw me in the car, and burn me up.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Whoops.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: That is a lighter, isn't it?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Greetings, everyone.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Thank God, the police.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Put the gun down, Alan. I'll take care of them.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Don't ever call me 'Irwin,' okay?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Under control? You idiot. You didn't know who he was?

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Fat Sam left the beach today. So did Gummy. It began to occur to me that some things are beginning to happen that maybe I should be aware of.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: What, 'long distance?' I couldn't help but hear you say something about Rio, Alan. You're not leaving with the eight hundred thousand dollars I staked you for the next load, are you?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Whoa. Well, you two obviously have a lot to talk over, so we'll go catch the last ten minutes of Dynasty.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: Your 'foolproof' way is going to land my a** on the front page while you're basking in Rio.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: ...with your money.

Speaker: cummings
Dialogue: This one's going to be even more fun.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Go ahead. Make my evening.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I'm calling the police. Then I'm leaving. You wait here for them.

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Away. I think it might take you a while to get your life back together. You don't need me around.  Don't go back in there.

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: I really creamed the sonofabitch, didn't I?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: You sure did.

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Your call is come through.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Far out.  Oh, tell Frank I need a couple of months. The fifty grand's lasting longer than I thought.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: I gotta go, Lar.

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: John Ultramalensky, right?

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: God, I haven't seen you since the wedding.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Gee, I must have been sh*t-faced at your wedding, I don't ---

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: Not mine, stupid. Yours.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: gail
Dialogue: I couldn't sit home and play the mournful widow anymore, and the police didn't need me, so I tried watching a Lakers game on TV, but the announcer talked to fast and I couldn't understand a lot of what was happening, so I figured if I came down here maybe you could explain the rules to me, and besides, I missed you.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: No problem.

Speaker: fletch
Dialogue: Basketball, of course, was invented in France, and is played with a large ball, two tongue depressors and a fish....
